No. 75.—INSCRIPTION AT TIRUKKALUKKUNRAM.

summary.p: This inscription (No. 179 of 1894) is engraved on the south wall of the second prākāra of the Vēdagirīśvara temple at Tirukkaḻukkuṉṟam.See page 143 above. It has been published before in a tentative manner by Mr. V. Kanakasabhai Pillai in the Indian Antiquary, Vol. XXI. p. 281 ff.Of the numerous misreadings in the transcript I need only note four, because they are connected with proper names. In line 35 of Mr. Kanakasabhai's text, the original does not read Viḻiña, but viḻunda; in l 42, not Koṅku, but Gaṅga; and in l. 43, not Sinkaḷam, but Śiṅgaṇam. The passage from Vikkilan (l. 28) to veṅkaḷiṛum (l. 31) is taken from the Kīḻappaḻuvūr and Tiruviḍaimarudūr inscriptions (Nos. 71 and 72 above), which read however Vikkalan instead of Vikkilan. The date is the 42nd year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. (l. 11).
The inscription records that an inhabitant of Rājarājapuram (l. 17) made over

10 kāśu (l. 14) to the temple authorities, who purchased for this sum from the villagers of Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-chaturvēdimaṅgalam (l. 11) some land for maintaining the Maṭha of Naminandi-Aḍigaḷ at Tirukkaḻukkuṉṟam (l. 14). As stated by Mr. Kanakasabhai,Ind. Ant. Vol. XXI. p. 284. the person after whom this Maṭha was named is one of the sixty-three devotees of Śiva, whose lives are described in the Periyapurāṇam.

Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-chaturvēdimaṅgalam belonged to Kumiḻi-nāḍu, a subdivision of the district of Āmūr-kōṭṭam (l. 11). The land purchased was situated in Kīraippākkam, a hamlet in the west of that village (l. 12), and was bounded in the east by Uroḍagam, in the south by Tāḻaivēḍu, in the west by Uragambākkam, and in the north by Taṇḍuṟai (l. 13). Kiraippākkam is the modern KīrappākkamNo. 264 on the Madras Survey Map of the Chingleput tāluka. in the Chingleput tāluka. East of it the map shows Oragaḍam (No. 228), south of it Tāḻambēḍu (No. 266), and north of it Taṇḍaṟai (No. 233). The nāḍu to which these villages belonged is named after KumiḻiNo. 19 on the same map. Compare Ep. Ind. Vol. III. p. 149. in the same tāluka. The district of Āmūr-kōṭṭam owes its name to the village of ĀmūrNo. 133 on the same map. near Māmallapuram,No. 162 on the same map. which belonged to the subdivision Āmūrnāḍu.Above, Vol. I. p. 68. From the Koṇḍyāta grant of Veṅkaṭa II.Ind. Ant. Vol. XIII. p. 132, plate iv. b, line 1, and Ep. Ind. Vol. IV. p. 271, note 5. it appears that there was another district which also bore the name of Āmūr-kōṭṭam, but which was named after the town of Āmūr or Āmbūr in the Vēlūr tāluka of the North Arcot district.Ep. Ind. Vol. IV. p. 180. The statement that Āmūr-nāḍu and the kōṭṭam to which it belonged were named after the town of Āmbūr (above, Vol. I. p. 126, note 2, and Ep. Ind. Vol. III. p. 149) is due to an error.

(Line 11.) In the forty-second year (of the reign) of • • • • • the emperor Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōḻadēva, who etc.The historical introduction of this inscription is the same as in No. 73. But it agrees with No. 72 in inserting a short passage after the words “in order that the enemies might be scattered.” This passage runs here: “(He) was pleased to seize the garland of that region, and the Gaṅga-maṇḍalam.” —we, the great assembly of Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-chaturvēdimaṅgalam in Kumiḻi-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Āmūr-kōṭṭam, (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōḻa-maṇḍalam, (drew up) a written deed of sale of land. We sold the following land, for maintainingOn puṟam see above, p. 6, note 9. a Maṭha, to Ādidāsa [Chaṇḍēśvara]dēvaSee above, Vol. I. p. 92 and note 6, and Vol. II. p. 134. in the temple of Tirukkaḻukkuṉṟam-uḍaiya-Mahādēvar, the lord of Ulagaḷanda-Śōḻapuram, alias Śembiyaṉ-Tirukkaḻukkuṉṟam,I.e. ‘Tirukkaḻukkuṉṟam (belonging to) the Chōḷa king.’ in [Kaḷattūr]-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Kaḷattūr-[kōṭṭam].
(L. 12.) The land sold (at) [Kī]raippākkam, a western hamlet of our village, has to be reclaimed by cutting down • • • • • the jungle and removing the stumps.

(L. 13.) The eastern boundary of (this land) adjoins the boundary of Uroḍagam; the southern boundary adjoins the boundary of Tāḻaivēḍu; the western boundary adjoins the boundary of U[ra]gamb[ākka]m; and the northern boundary adjoins the boundary of [Ta]ṇḍuṟai.

(L. 14.) Having freed from taxes the wet land and the dry land, the trees above and the wells below, [enclosed within these four boundaries], and sold (it) for maintaining the Maṭha of Naminandi-Aḍigaḷ, which is situated in the MaḍaiviḷāgamI.e. the environs of the temple; see above, p. 24 and note 3. of this village, we received as price ten good kāśu current at the time.See above, p. 134 and note 5.

(L. 15.) Having sold • • • • • and having received the money in full, we, the great assembly, made and gave a deed of sale. Having agreed that we alone should be bound to pay the small taxes, the big taxes,The two terms śil-vari and peru-vari occur also in Vol. I. p. 87, text line 6. and any other (tax) due on this land, we sold (it) free from taxes. By order of [Karā]mbichcheṭṭuCompare above, p. 73 and note 7. [Sarv]ādittaṉ, who belonged (?) to the sabhā, we, • • • • • Bhaṭṭaṉ, Ma[ḻa]ppirāṉ Kumārasāmi-Kramavittaṉ, Aruḷāḷa-BhaṭṭaṉSee above, p. 143, note 1. of Uṟuppuṭṭūr,The same village is mentioned on page 4 above. Śrīraṅganātha-Bhaṭṭaṉ of Paśumbuṟam, Śaṁkaranārāyaṇa-Bhaṭṭaṉ of Uṟuppuṭṭūr, Tillaikkūtta-KramavittaṉSee above, Vol. II. p. 253, and p. 258, note 6. of Kura[va]ś[ē]ri, and Dōṇaśūra-KramavittaṉDōṇa is a Prākṛit form of Drōṇa. Compare Dōṇaśarman, Dōnaya, Dōniya, etc. in Ep. Ind. Vol. V. Index. of Kirāñji,The same village is mentioned in an inscription at Śevilimēḍu near Conjeeveram; Ep. Ind. Vol. VI. p. 230. —all these members of the great assembly made and gave (this) writing [on stone, to last as long as] the moon and the sun.

(L. 17.) This is the writing of Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-Uḍaiyāṉ Śelvaṉ Kuḻaiñāṉ. This charity was made by me, Dēvandainādaṉ Aruḷāḷaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōḻa-Māpodiyarāyaṉ,The last member of this title means ‘the great king of the Podiyam (mountain).’ On Podiyam see above, Vol. II. p. 236, note 1. of Rājarājapuram in Eyiṟkōṭṭam.
